title: DICTIONARY COMPREHENSION FILTERS
production_snippet:
data = {'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 3}
result = {k: v for k, v in data.items() if v > 1}
script: Stop writing multi-line loops just to filter a dictionary! Use dictionary comprehension with a condition. Cleaner, faster, Pythonic.

title: MERGING DICTS THE RIGHT WAY
script: Ditch the `copy` and `update`! Use the `|` operator to merge dictionaries. It's concise and handles overlapping keys gracefully. No more accidental mutations!

title: ITERTOOLS.CHAIN
code_snippet:
list1 = [1, 2, 3]
list2 = [4, 5, 6]
for item in list1 + list2:
  print(item)
production_snippet:
import itertools
list1 = [1, 2, 3]
list2 = [4, 5, 6]
for item in itertools.chain(list1, list2):
  print(item)
script: Don't use `+` to combine lists for iteration! Use `itertools.chain`. It's memory-efficient, especially with large lists. Avoids creating unnecessary copies.

title: ENUMERATE START INDEX
code_snippet:
items = ['a', 'b', 'c']
index = 1
for item in items:
  print(index, item)
  index += 1
script: Stop manually incrementing indexes in `for` loops! `enumerate` accepts a `start` argument. It makes your code cleaner and less error-prone.

title: ZIP MULTIPLE LISTS
code_snippet:
names = ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie']
ages = [25, 30, 28]
cities = ['NY', 'London', 'Paris']
for i in range(len(names)):
    print(names[i], ages[i], cities[i])
production_snippet:
names = ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie']
ages = [25, 30, 28]
cities = ['NY', 'London', 'Paris']
for name, age, city in zip(names, ages, cities):
    print(name, age, city)
script: Avoid manual indexing when iterating over multiple lists. Use `zip` to iterate through them in parallel. It's more readable and Pythonic!
